dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in a simple, small but comfortable hotel room with bare white walls and worn out but well-kept hardwood floo There’s a small bed with someone seemingly asleep in it; desk and a chair in the corner. Around the window, we see faint frame of early morning light, but the curtains are drawn closed, keeping the room dark and tranquil. After a few seconds, we notice a quiet but steady sound “drip... drip... drip..." breaking the absolute silence. On the bed, PAUL GAGNE has his eyes open, awake in the darkness. A light-haired Frenchman in his mid 30’s, he listens to the steady beat of water falling one drop afte the next into a lonesome metal can. He can hear a piano start to play in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s morning of a Fall day in Sintra, the ancient Portugu city on the hills, not far from Lisbon. For centuries, th was the summer retreat for the local aristocracy. The orn towers of various castles, each in its own architectural style, are seen above the more typical Colonial-era build that make up the heart of the town. There’s green all aro from its famous lush gardens. The effect is romantic - al fairy tale. The streets are still quiet in town. It’s early in the morning. The tour buses have not yet arrived. The lucky tourists who managed to get a room in town are still asle Well, not all of them. JAMES “JIMMY” MANUS, a robust Irishman, early 60's, tall and gentle, strolls amongst a LOCALS. Looking down, hands in his pockets, he is deep in thought. It’s a beautiful day in Sintra, but Jimmy is una of his magnificent surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jimmy turns the corner, something makes him slow down. It’s nothing more than an old fountain adorned with beaut tile work. He stops to listen to the sound of the working fountain and, as if hit by a wave of nostalgia, he slowly approaches the water stream. And as Jimmy touches the wat his eyes fill up with tears.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We call that Fonte dos Noivados - The Engagement Fountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing on top of a sloped street, an elegant older man silver hair, adjusts his BINOCULARS, trying to get the sc down below, of Jimmy at the fountain, into focus. The friendly looking Frenchman in his early 60's is MICHE GAGNE. Next to him is TIAGO MIRANTE, a striking, young Portuguese guide.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The tile work is from the late 18th Century, from the reign of Dona Maria I. At that time, unmarried girls would come from all over the region to drink from this ancient fountain. They’d do this pilgrimage because there was a belief that the waters would help them find a good husband. Michel lets his binoculars fall to his chest, and hang fr their straps.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: And did it work?

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: They say so.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: How magnificent. If only it was so easy. Tiago smiles benignly, then starts down the street, watch by Michel.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: (to himself) Magnifique.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue water. The surface of transparent blue water tremble projecting abstract forms. A woman’s hand touches the water, a reflection of her fac still abstract, fills the screen. She seems to be looking herself... or at the bottom of the pool.  3. FRANCOISE “FRANKIE” CREMONT, kneeling by the pool, dips o hand into the water, then the other one, making sure both wrists are wet and cool. As if part of a ritual, she then splashes water on the back of her neck. Once, twice. Frankie gets up and, meditative, keeping her eyes down at water, takes a deep breath. She’s a striking woman, with very short haircut, messy like a boy’s, accentuating her strong features.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: MAYA, 15, light-skinned black, in shorts and a tank top, lying on a lounge chair by the pool reading Wuthering Heights. She looks up from her book, inquisitive, recogni something, or someone she knows.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Frankie drops the bathrobe. She’s topless, wearing only t bottom part of a bikini. Another deep breath, and she div into the swimming pool. Maya puts her book down, and watches as Frankie swims und water, and comes to the surface close to her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: (British accent) There’s people in the hotel, you know.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I don’t see anyone.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: They can take pictures.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: That's okay. I’m very photogenic. Maya observes as Frankie swims away, her semi-naked body moving gracefully under the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A traditional Portuguese bakery with glass shelves filled with the freshest, most delicious pastries. It’s all so f you can almost smell it. Behind the counter is LUCIANA, serving Jimmy, placing pastries in a takeaway box. Jimmy sipping an expresso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that’s four queijadas. And now, let's see... six pastéis, please.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIANA
dialogues.text: You look tired today. Did you not get enough sleep?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Well thank you very much. Another SALESWOMAN, standing next to Luciana, laughs at w she’s just heard.

dialogues.speaker: SALESWOMAN
dialogues.text: Luciana!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: So nice to hear first thing in the morning! The Saleswoman laughs some more. Luciana blushes.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIANA
dialogues.text: Sorry, I didn’t... anyway, tired is sexy! Luciana hands him his box of pastries.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I'll pretend I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIANA
dialogues.text: (in Portuguese) His eyes are puffy. He's been crying. (in English) Have a nice day, Mr. Jimmy. Say hello to the Madame. Luciano goes to help other customers.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I have terrible allergies. If you want to know.

dialogues.speaker: LUCIANA
dialogues.text: My husband too. It’s awful this time of the year. Jimmy takes another sip from his espresso, trying to enjo the Portuguese morning.  INT. QUINTA DE SAO THIAGO/IAN & SYLVIA’S SUITE - DAY 7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IAN ANDOH, 46, an Englishman, black, solidly built, sits the bed, wearing shorts, holding a running shoe. He tries put the shoe on, but it’s too tight. He picks it up again and as he loosens up the shoe laces, working meticulously from the top part down, a recurring thought manifests its

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: The whole thing is so unfair. I can’t get over it. They’re one of the happiest, most perfectly romantic pairs I have ever known. Ian’s wife SYLVIA ANDOH, late 30's, stands across the hot suite, dressed in pants and a bra, picking up a shirt fro open suitcase. They must have been a happy couple at some point. Now, approaching middle age, something sets them apart.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: There’s no perfection there. They have their grievances. Ian puts on the running shoe.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Have you seen my yellow cashmere sweater?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: To think that one is suddenly taken away from the other by this... thing, this horrible thing, makes me lose faith in love itself.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: So romantic, all of a sudden!

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Don’t be cynical. We’re seeing your father go from romantic bliss to tears and despair. Ian stands up and grabs a T-shirt, but before he puts it he looks at himself in the mirror, and grabs his own love handles.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I have to stop with the bread.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’ve gained weight.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Don’t start. Please. Ian puts the T-shirt on. Sylvia closes down the suitcase, frustrated that she can’t find what she was looking for.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: What day is it today? Thursday?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Wednesday. She goes in the drawer, grabs the first shirt she sees an puts it on.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: It’s impossible to pretend we are enjoying this trip. It’s a brutal idea she had. For us all to come here at a time like this.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: You sure it wasn’t your father’s idea?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: What do you think? Sylvia goes out the door, leaving Ian alone with his weig and his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy is walking out with his box of pastries when he run into Michel and Tiago.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: You beat us this morning!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: “I'd woken early, and I took a long time getting ready to exist.” Michel isn’t sure he understands.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fernando Pessoa. I just can’t help it. My mind swims with him whenever I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Jimmy, you are the only actor I know who reads anything but their reviews. Jimmy laughs, and then offers his box of pastries.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Queijadas anyone? Or a pastel?

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: How is she this morning?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: She's good, thanks. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: And you?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I’m here in this magical town with the people I love most. I have no right to complain, do I?

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: I believe everyone always has a right to complain, don’t you, Tiago?

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: Certainly. The three men smile at each other awkwardly. INT. QUINTA DE SAO THIAGO/FRANKIE & JIMMY’S SUITE - DAY 9 Frankie, already dressed, her hair still wet, goes to the dresser and picks up a cardigan sweater.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Will this one do? As Frankie hands Sylvia the sweater, Sylvia notices a bracelet Frankie has on her wrist, and grabs her hand to a better look.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Wait a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it gorgeous?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Is it real?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Pink diamonds, Colombian emeralds. It’s Bulgari, vintage.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: How come I’ve never seen this one before?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: It was given to me by a man I knew between Michel and your father. There were quite a few, you know. I was younger than you are now. And very beautiful. I never wear it. Not because of your father - he doesn’t care. But it’s a bit flashy, no?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: It’s Bulgari.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I'm always afraid it’ll get stolen or something, but now I’m like ‘what the hell’.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Can I try? Frankie places the bracelet onto Sylvia’s wrist. There's knock on the door, but the girls are too excited to hear anything else but themselves. Sylvia admires the stones against the light.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: He must’ve really loved you, this man. The door opens and Paul comes in. He’s straight out of be hasn’t even washed his face yet.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Love? I don’t know. He liked me, and he was rich. I try never to confuse money with love. He said the colors were perfect for me. Whatever that means.  9. Paul gives his mother a double kiss on her cheeks and goe sit on the bed, without a word.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: My room has a terrible leak.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Well, good morning.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can’t sleep.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Try another room.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I asked. Nothing available.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Is the water dripping on you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, it’s in the corner. But still, it’s all night, “drip... drip... drip...” It’s impossible.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: You're too sensitive.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You want to switch rooms?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: You want to sleep with my husband?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Question is: do you want to sleep with your husband?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: None of your business!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You started this.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Children. I haven’t even had coffee yet. A beat. Paul keeps staring at Sylvia, defiant, but this i sensitive matter Sylvia would rather not discuss. All ver clear to Frankie.  10.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I’m going to get some sun. You should try it sometime, Paul. Would be good for your skin. Sylvia walks towards the door...

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Vivi! Sylvia turns around, takes the bracelet off.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I forgot. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Don’t forget sun screen; especially there, on the side. Sylvia gives him an annoyed look.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sun can be so unforgiving to your wrinkles. Frankie puts the bracelet back on, as Sylvia exits. Frankie is now alone with her son Paul. She goes to the bathroom mirror and starts putting some makeup on. Paul follows her. The conversation that follows, as will all between French mother and son, is in FRENCH.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Je me sens hyper malhereux.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Bah oui bien sir.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Merci pour 1’ironie! Frankie doesn’t need much. eyeliner, lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm so terribly unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You're being ironic! Moisturizing cream, and a little

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, mon chéri, je suis mieux placée que n’importe qui pour savoir qu’elles ne sont pas toutes roses, ces vacances. Mais tu es jeune, tu as la santé, tu pars vivre @ New York dans le West Village, et on profite d’une des villes le plus romantiques au monde sous un soleil magnifique. Qu’est-ce qu’il te faut de plus?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Je crois que je suis toujours amoureux d’Anne-Shophie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Oh non pitié. Pas Possible.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Pourquoi?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Tu restes avec ces filles deux ans. Tu n’es pas sir de les aimer, donc elles te quittent. Une fois qu’elles sont parties, bingo, tu découvres qu’en fait tu es amoureux d’elles! Béatrice, Julie, Anne-Sophie, et qui encore?!... A chaque fois c'est la méme histoire! Tu tournes en rond, et quand ce n'est pas ga... enfim bref. En tous cas, il faut que tu arrétes. Ca fait quoi, quasiment deux ans qu’Anne- Sophie et toi avez rompu? Tu ne peux plus 6tre amoureux d’elle, ce n’est pas possible.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Pour quelqu’un qui prétend croire a l’amour éternel...

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Eternel? Je n’irais peut-étre pas jusque 1a. 11.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Oh honey, I, more than anyone, am aware that this trip is not a happy event. But, Paul, you're young and healthy, you're moving to the West Village in New York City, and it is a sunny day in one of the most romantic cities in the world. What else do you want?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I think I'm still in love with Anne-Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Oh no, please! That can not be.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You stay with these girls for two years. You're not sure you love them, so they break up with you. Then, after they leave, you find out you're actually in love! Beatrice, Julie, Anne-Sophie! Always the same! You're going in circles, and if you don't - anyway, that has to stop. You and Anne-Sophie split up, what - almost two years now? You simply cannot still be in love with her.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I thought you were the one who believed that love can last forever.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Forever? I don't know about that.  10

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: En tout cas Jimmy et toi avez l‘air plus amoureux aujourd'hui que du temps de votre rencontre.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Mais Paul, elle t’a quitté. C’est absurde. Quand tu rencontreras la femme de ta vie, tu l’oublieras, Anne- Sophie. Tu vas voir.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ah oui, tu parle comme tu la connais déja, la femme de ma vie? 12.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You and Jimmy seem to be more in love now then when you two first met.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: But Paul, she left you. It's absurd. Once you meet the right woman, you'll forget about Anne-Sophie. You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You talk as if you knew who the right one might be.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Eh bah oui, peut-étre. I do.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL PAUL
dialogues.text: Bravo. Splendid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ILENE BIANCHI, a great looking woman, early 50’s with youthful charm, and dark, winsome eyes, pulls a small car on bag up a street behind the historic Palace of Sintra.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: My problem is the story. If I could just get that right, you know? I think I could really make something good. Something great, even. Ilene looks around as she walks, her curious and peaceful eyes enchanted by the views of Sintra.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: But I just can’t get my head around a conventional three-act structure, and they want that. She's followed by GARY TOMLINSON, a shaggy, sandy-haired American, mid 50’s, also pulling a carry-on bag.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Anyone who might finance it at least. The first act - man, that’s something, you know? And then the second - isn’t that enough? A third just seems gratuitous.  11 13. Gary is completely uninterested in the view, but Ilene kn him well, and is able to shut him out in her head. She le him talk as they keep walking up the street.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I'm interested in all of it. Story is just one part. I see geography as destiny, you know what I mean? I’m interested in what constitutes intimacy, identity, community; how we communicate... with ourselves, with our surroundings, and how these human constructs can be rendered in image and performance. As they turn a corner, the colorful Palacio da Pena, on t of the hill, comes into view.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Do you think it’s crazy to think about shooting on 35? It would be so amazing. Ilene? The view of the multi-colored fantasy castle is a wonder, Ilene pauses to take it in.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Ilene? Are you even listening to me?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Wow. They were right. Looks like something out of a fairy tale. She looks out at the busy, beautiful town in front of her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small group of YOUNG GIRLS in Catholic school uniform w down the street. They pass Paul, who smiles, and tries hi well-rehearsed Portuguese:

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Bom dia. But the girls are not interested. They don’t respond, but that doesn’t faze Paul. He breathes the air of Sintra, lo around at his magnificent surroundings, and it makes him good. Just up the street, there’s a little FLOWER STAND, displa local plants and flowers in unexpected, artful arrangemen  14. As Paul passes by, he notices the very pretty girl, BIANC early 20's, with pale white skin, dark hair, and piercing green eyes, behind the stand putting together a new arrangement. Paul slows down. He can’t believe his eyes, so he turns around and, discreetly, looks back at her. There she is, a vision, putting together different plants, making artfu arrangements. Paul decides to walk back.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Bom dia.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Bom dia. Paul checks out the flowers, while discreetly checking ou the girl. He picks up an arrangement, and smells it deepl

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hmmm... The smell!

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Lavanda is the best.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Reminds me of someone.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Someone you love.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Someone I used to.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: She broke your heart?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She married somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Ah, I see. She keeps working on her arrangement, while Paul chooses another to smell.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Which one would you say is the most sensual?  15.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Depends on who you're buying it for.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: A very beautiful girl. I think she'd like what you like. She smiles, and puts down her arrangement to go assist Pa She chooses a big bouquet, and hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: What do you think of this one? They are interrupted by the arrival of a young man, JOAO MIGUEL, bringing an armful of fresh plants and flowers. H senses something in the air, as Bianca goes behind the counter, back to her arrangement. Paul, smelling the flow is caught off guard.

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (in scratchy Portuguese) Quanto custa?

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: Quinze. Feefteem. Paul hands him a fifty Euro bill.

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: No. Feefteem. One five.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sorry, that’s all I have.

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: Wait one minute. My girl goes for change. But she is back at work on her elaborate arrangement and shrugs at his suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: Bianca, please go get some change for the Senor, ao restaurante.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nao ves que estou ocupada? Tenho que terminar isto até ao meio dia. Vai 14 tu.

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: O que 6 que se passa aqui? Vai buscar o troco, que eu cuido do cliente.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Estou a meio dum arranjo! Nao vou a lado nenhum

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: Estou a interromper alguma coisa, 6? 16.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Don't you see that I'm busy? I have to finish this by noon. You can go get it.

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: What I see, I don't like. Go get change. I'll take care of the customer.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: But I'm making a big bouquet. I'm not going anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: Am I interrupting something here? What's going on? Paul watches in disbelief as the whole thing escalates to full blown argument.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Nao se passa nada!

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: Eu conhego-te...

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Estas louco!

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: .+.eu vi os olhinhos que ele te estava a deitar.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: O que 6 que estas pr’aia dizer? Tens de comfiar mais em mim, Joao Miguel. S6 estou a vender flores.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: Nothing is going on!

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: Oh, please...

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: You're crazy!

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: .-.The way he was looking at you.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? You have to trust me, Joao Miguel I'm just trying to sell flowers. Paul holds the bouquet, unsure of what to do.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Please keep the change.

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: No! She goes for change. Bianca is not going anywhere.  12 17.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA BIANCA
dialogues.text: Para 14 com esses ciumes. You have to stop being so jealous. Bianca can’t hold back her tears. She starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Se trabalhamos juntos, tens We're trying to work que confiar em mim. Eu nao together, but you don't trust aguento mais. Assim nao me. I can't go on like this. posso. E sério que nao. I can't. I can't.

dialogues.speaker: JOAO MIGUEL JOAO MIGUEL
dialogues.text: Bianca. Desculpa, amor. Bianca. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BIANCA BIANCA
dialogues.text: Desculpas nao chegam. That's not enough. Paul surreptitiously takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sylvia is outside the Quinta, on a small dirt road to the side, talking on her cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (on her phone) I know, I saw your messages but I specifically asked for two bedrooms. Oh, so I could turn that into a second bedroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, but that would cost a fortune. Listen, my daughter is going to college in a few years. I don’t need two bathrooms. And I don’t mind if we have to go a bit further West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.. or) ; For comparison maybe. It’s just too far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wee) Thank you, talk to you soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sylvia hangs up and steps to the side to look at the view She breathes it in, and tries to make her troubles go awa it is a gorgeous place, but the tension on her face does dissipate. Sintra’s gardens and fabulous private villas s a world away.  18.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom? Maya, in shorts and a T-shirt, carries a backpack, ready a day out.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: (shows her cellphone) I couldn't get any reception inside.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Is this about the flat?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Why would you think that?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: ‘Cause you look all sneaky there. I downloaded WhatsApp for you. You can just use an internet connection, you don’t need a phone line.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I tried, but you have to show me how to use it. Maya rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Dad was asking if I knew anything about a flat.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Did you say anything?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Not much.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: What do you mean, “not much”?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: I said I didn’t know.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: No, it’s not good!  19. Maya walks away, towards another part of the garden, wher she has left her books and papers on a large stone table. begins to pack her things, when Sylvia joins her.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Honey, Maya. Listen to me, let’s not argue.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: You know your father’s just fishing around. He’s looking for something that isn’t there.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: You're insane.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Don’t use that word.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Why not? You tell me lying is the worst thing I could do, ever, and then you ask me to lie for you!

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Maya, you’re not lying. You’re just holding information. Your father shouldn't know anything before there’s something real to know. I’1l tell him when the time is right.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Don’t you think he knows when I’m lying? (almost crying) You always make me do this!

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I’m not making you. I’m sorry. I’m just struggling that’s all. Come here baby. You’re my best friend, baby. I don’t want to make you unhappy. Sylvia tries to hug Maya, but Maya is not up to it - she pulls away.  20.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Oh, please, Sylvia! I can’t see how your moving out won’t make us more unhappy!

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Stop calling me Sylvia! I’m your mother!

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Mother or best friend? Which one is it?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Why can’t I be both? Maya starts to walk away. Then she stops, and turns aroun

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Can I have some euros, please?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Just twenty. Twenty euros.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Not if you don’t tell me what it is for.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: I want to be independent today. Sylvia reaches in her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Here’s a ten. She hands it to Maya.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Thank you. Maya walks away. Fast. She leaves the courtyard and heads the road outside the Quinta. Sylvia catches up with her, calls out.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Maya! Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: (calling out to Sylvia behind her) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MAYA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not independence day if I tell you. Maya continues, and Sylvia puts her foot down.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Stop. Look at me. Maya follows orders, stops, and turns to look at Sylvia.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t go very far. You know we’re all meeting at Peninha in the afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: It’s a place at the top of the mountain, that Frankie’s determined for all of us to see.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: I can’t promise. Maya turns and continues on.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Maya! It’s for Frankie. Maya kicks a little rock on the dirt road.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Fuck Frankie! She’s not even my grandmother. Sylvia can’t hear her. She’s already far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilene is by the “Engagement Fountain.” She reaches out, cupping her hand and, thirsty, drinks a few sips of the water. Paul, carrying his bouquet of flowers, passes by as Ilene drinking the water. They don’t see each other. Ilene sits on the little bench that surrounds the Fountai with her bag, and Gary’s, next to her. She refreshes hers splashing some cold fresh water on her neck, on her face. sits reading a Frommer's Portugal guide, waiting.  22. Ilene raises her eyes from her book, distracted, and recognizes someone on the street. Jimmy comes down on the other side of the street, carryin his little box of pastries.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jimmy! He sees Ilene waving, but he doesn’t think it’s for him. Ilene stands up, and smiles. Jimmy can’t dismiss her. It’ for him, and he comes her way.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m lost.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I’m not a local, but - What are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Jimmy. It’s me, Ilene. Jimmy looks at Ilene with some recollection, but still uncertain of her identity.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I worked with Frankie in New York. On Noah Baumbach’s movie.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Ilene!

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I was her hairstylist.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Of course. I’m so sorry. What a small world to run into you here. How wonderful! He gives her a big hug.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Didn’t Frankie mention...?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Frankie talks about you all the time.  23.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: That’s sweet. You know she’s the only actress in all my years of working in film that I’ve become real friends with. But with the distance, it can be hard to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Just the other day I was trying to remember the name of that restaurant you took us to last time we were in New York. I wanted to recommend it to a friend.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It was a classic American steak house. Very good.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Keen’s! On 36th Street.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yes, that was it. Amazing.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: You liked that mutton chop, huh?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I loved that mutton chop. But was that the last time we saw you? I thought maybe in London, also?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: No, I haven’t been to London yet, but I’m hoping to. It’s been a long time.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: And now, “lo, Cintra’s glorious Eden intervenes!”

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I just read that! How funny. She motions with her guide book.  24.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: “Lo! Cintra's glorious Eden intervenes In variegated maze of mount and glen. Ah me! what hand can pencil guide, or pen, To follow half on which the eye dilates Through views more dazzling unto mortal ken Than those whereof such things the bard relates, Who to the awe-struck world unlocked Elysium's gates?”

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I don’t know much about Byron, I’m embarrassed to say, but it’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Oh, I wouldn’t know anything about him except I had to memorize that poem for my Leaving Certificate. He seems to have been everywhere, though. Every town in Europe seems to claim him. And he had scandalous affairs in each stop. In Greece, they consider him a national hero. As boys, we thought his stuff was very sexy to read, believe it or not. Really romantic.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Sounds like a full life...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Well, he did die very young.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Didn't they all? But wouldn’t you rather live a life full of passion and adventure, even if it’s short, than go through an endless, monotonous string of the day after day after day?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t know. It’s easy to say life is wonderful when you go from one adventure to another, but Byron suffered quite a lot. Anyway, that’s not reality for most people. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Certainly not for me. I think that to try and find beauty in everyday life, when you might think that things are dragging on... that is kind of better. The most difficult, but the most rewarding, maybe. Jimmy pauses. Ilene looks into his eyes, taking in his po of view, reflecting. Then she smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: You don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: No, I- Gary approaches, as Jimmy and Ilene continue their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I’ve been in Spain, working on the new Star Wars movie. We have a well deserved break.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Star Wars??

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: It’s actually a good job.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I’m sure. I didn’t mean, I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: No, don’t worry. Of course. But they pay well. And for the most part the people are nice. It’s a great crew. And Spain is so wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Does that mean Chewbacca is going to have a new hairdo? Ilene laughs. Gary steps in.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Well, I tried a Farrah Fawcett on him, but in the end-  26.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Shush! Sorry. Gary is instantly in the middle of the conversation. He w at Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: We signed a confidentiality agreement.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Ok. Jimmy isn’t sure if that’s supposed to be funny, but he understands that this is Ilene’s friend, so they shake ha

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It’s ridiculous, but it’s Star Wars. They are very serious about it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Uh hum. On the other side of the street, Michel observes the scen quietly, with Tiago next to him, smoking a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Hi, I’m Gary. I’m also working on the film. Second unit DP.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Gary, this is Jimmy, Frankie's husband.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Wow. You’re Frangoise Cremont’s husband? I’m a huge fan. You’re a lucky man.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I know I am.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: So did you find it?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Nobody knows. I don’t understand these people, or they don’t understand me. I thought we were right next to it, but apparently-- Michel steps in.  27.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Maybe I can help.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Michel, this is Ilene, a good friend of Frankie’s from New York, and this is... He can’t remember Gary’s name, so Gary steps in.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Gary. Gary Tomlinson. They all shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: I’m Frankie’s first husband.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Paul’s dad.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Of course. I’ve heard so much about you.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I like the sound of that.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: No, all good things. Frankie says you have the best seafood restaurant in all of Paris.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: The best? I don’t know. That’s very Frankie. Tiago approaches.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: This is Tiago. A true local, born and raised here in Sintra.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: Where are you trying to go?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Quinta da Boica. Michel gets one of the bags, gestures for Gary to pick up other one.  28.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Tiago. Quinta da Boica.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: Boiga (has an ‘s’ sound). Not Boica.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Yes, Boiga.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Ha! That’s why you couldn’t find it.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: Follow me. Gary and Michel, carrying the bags, follow Tiago. Jimmy seems to suddenly realize that he’s holding a box o pastries, and offers one to Ilene.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Would you like a pastry?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Please! Ilene takes a queijada from the box.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: It’s nice to see a woman in the movie business who will eat a pastry.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Oh, I eat everything. It’s the reason to travel.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: This place is really something. You're going to love it. Ilene takes a first bite of pastry.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ilene! Let’s go!

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Hmm. This is delicious. She smiles politely to Jimmy, and catches up with Gary.  14 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An exquisite park, with old stone gates, small lakes and views. Sylvia carries the flower bouquet Paul bought, while he w next to her.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Are you excited about New York?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m looking forward to it. But excited? I can’t be excited about anything at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Did you get the sublet?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m not sure.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I haven’t sent the documents yet.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Since I got the news, I haven’t been able to concentrate. I can’t work, I can’t think about anything else.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: When you get bad news, you should focus on the practical stuff.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s too overwhelming.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: There’s nothing better to remedy an overwhelming situation than having to fill out paperwork. Did you call the number I gave you, the tax lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes, I called him. What an arrogant guy. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He says I should try to convince my mother to incorporate with me and Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I’ll talk to my dad. You should talk to Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: This is the last subject I want to bring up with her.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Then you’1ll have to pay the ridiculous inheritance tax.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You're so...

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Pragmatic?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That’s one word for it.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: It’s just life, Paul. I don’t make as much money as you do. And when you have a teenage daughter, you get practical.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Maybe. Sylvia takes a long pause, and then braves it.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I’m going to leave Ian.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: How many times have I heard this?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: This time is for real. I can’t do it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Is that why you’re calculating your inheritance?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Stop it. You can’t say that to me.  They look Paul puts gesture, 31.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s just that I’ve been hearing you say this for so long. The timing is interesting.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: You are so fucking self righteous.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Come to New York.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Why would I come to New York?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: New life, new city.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: It’s not that easy.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, it’s not. at each other, understanding.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: This is all just so horrible. I can’t believe it, really. I just can’t. his arm around her, and Sylvia welcomes the and returns the affection. That’s when Paul tries to kiss her. It’s a surprise for Sylvia, a flowers t nd she pushes him away, dropping the bouquet of o the ground.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: You know... that might have been romantic when we were teenagers.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Even better now. We have more life experience.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Sometimes I really hate you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I’m serious about you coming to New York. I need the pragmatism. You need to get away from Ian.  32.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Oh, you have no sense of your privilege. If I could get a job in banking, maybe I would. But they’re not hiring philosophy majors at Credit Suisse these days.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You wouldn't want a job at Credit Suisse.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Oh, wouldn’t I? Don’t make too many assumptions. You want to help me? Do me a favor. Talk to your mother about the incorporating idea. It'll save everybody a lot of money. It’ll be good for Dad, too. And yes, if it helps my father, he will be able to help me. I’m sorry to even talk about these things, but it’s true. Paul looks at her, dismayed.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t judge me, Paul. Don’t judge me. I am doing the best I can. So don’t you dare sit there from your smug and ugly unhappiness and look down on me. At least I’m trying to change things. She walks away, as Paul picks up the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie and Jimmy walk through another area of the garden Frankie carries the box of pastries, biting with delight queijada.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: How does she look?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: She looks great. Better. How long ago was that film?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Five years ago. Maybe six.  33.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: She was too skinny when we were in New York.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: She just looks more mature.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Arréte. Jimmy!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: “Mature” is offensive! To a woman, particularly.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Wouldn’t it be wonderful if she and Paul get along?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ilene and Paul. New York can be a very lonely city. They would be good for each other.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus, Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You invited her! This is all...

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I think she would be just perfect for him.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Christ, Frankie. You’re playing Cupid again.  34.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Don't “Christ, Frankie” me. You of all people should understand. I don’t want Paul to end up alone.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Don’t let the kids find out that this was your idea. They’d go mad. This was supposed to be a family trip.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: It still is. Family with a “Plus One,” so what?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You come up with these crazy scenarios in your head. You think you can manipulate everything.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I’m usually right. Jimmy starts to laugh. Frankie laughs with him, thinking about her comment, but soon he’s laughing harder. She realizes it’s something else.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Well.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: What’s so funny?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I have news for you, darling.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Ilene brought a friend.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: A friend?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Oh yes, Ilene is accompanied by Gary, I believe that’s his name, a friend who looks very much like her boyfriend, if you want to know my opinion.  16 35.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Mais non!! She wasn’t supposed to bring anyone. Frankie is not happy.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Quel surprise. Jimmy throws his arm around upset Frankie, and gives her kiss: he loves her, machinations and everything.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: We will see!

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Come, let’s go. I want to take you to a place I’ve read about. She pulls away from him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: No. I’m hiking to Peninha.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: There’s more than enough time, love. We'll get there.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: The one thing I don’t have is time.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Don’t get melodramatic on me. Just come on, no complaining. Jimmy takes her hand, and they walk down the path togethe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilene sips tea, alone on the terrace of a small and beautifully renovated house, a private Quinta. There’s a swimming pool down below, and a view to the immense green valley. Gary comes out to join her; he’s holding something behind back.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I wasn’t expecting this. The photos on the site don’t do it justice. They should hire me to take new pictures. This place is incredible.  36.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: This is so nice, Gary. It must be very expensive.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It's fine. George Lucas been berry berry good to me.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: To both of us! But who knows what the next job will be.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: That's why I want to make this movie. I can’t be a cameraman forever. I need to change gears, before it’s too late.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I hope so. Gary pulls his hand from behind, holding a small gift box

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Here. I have something for you. Ilene’s surprised. He gives her the box.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Oh, God. He gives her a kiss. It’s a bit clumsy.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I hope you like it. Ilene tries to smile. She wasn’t expecting this.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Open it. She does. Inside the box, a silver ring, with a small det in gold. It’s a designer ring, very modern, young.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Gary, you shouldn't have done this.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Why? You said you liked it.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I know I did, but still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I walked by the store before we left Valencia, and it was still in the window. Ilene closes the box, with the ring inside.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what I’ve been thinking?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: No. What were you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I’ve been thinking I want us to spend more time together.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yes. I had an idea of getting rid of my apartment in the city and just moving into the house in Water Mill full time. Making a real home out there. Gary tries to look directly into Ilene’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You could come and stay for as long as you wanted. And whenever one of us is working in the city, we could stay at your place.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: That’s a lot of plans, all of a sudden.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: We'd have a beautiful house on the beach, and I’d help with the rent on a nice apartment on the Upper West Side. We’d have two homes. We don’t need more than that. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Oh. I don’t know. For me Water Mill is more like a weekend place. I like it, but for the beach, and to get away. 37.  17 18 38.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: A lot of people live there full time and still work in the city. It’s really not very far. And besides, with more time in Water Mill, you could paint more, or write, or do any of those things you always say you'd like more time for. Without my apartment, we'd both save money. You wouldn’t need to work so much. Ilene looks out onto the vast view of the valley in front them.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ilene, I'd like to be with you. For us to be together.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Is this a proposal?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I didn’t think of it that way, but I guess it is. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I say let’s go out. We just got here. The ring is beautiful, Gary. Thank you. I love it. Thank you. Now come on, get your coat, get your camera. Let’s go. Let’s see where we are before we plan the future. Ilene walks into the house. Gary stays with the view for moment, then goes inside after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old fashioned, open TRAM crosses a bucolic green corri of leafy trees and tall grass. Later, it passes by a small town comprised almost exclusi of old, small white houses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tram is in motion, and Maya is sitting inside, writin a small notebook. She finishes a sentence and looks out, seeing the small town pass by.  39. Maya goes back to her notebook, trying to concentrate aga when she’s interrupted by a couple of Portuguese boys, PE and BENTO, a bit older, around 16 years old, who are sitt behind her. Pedro leans in.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: O que voce esta escrevendo?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: (hard Portuguese accent) Desculpa, eu nao falo...

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: Yes, you do. You speak very well. Maya is able to understand that he’s playing with her, an makes a bigger effort.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Eu nao falo portugues. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: I see. That’s ok. What are you writing?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: Are you going to the beach?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: I am. She turns around, and looks at them. She sees that they c boogie boards with them.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: I take it this is the right direction.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: I’m from England, the East Midlands, but my family moved to London last year. You?

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: I’m from Porto, a few hours to the North. Bento here is from Sintra.  40.

dialogues.speaker: BENTO
dialogues.text: I live in Sintra. Are you here on vacation?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: BENTO
dialogues.text: What is it then? Maya avoids the question.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Hey, can I rent a boogie board on the beach? Pedro gets up and comes to sit next to Maya.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: No. But you can use mine.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: No, that’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: Bento has one too. We can take turns.

dialogues.speaker: BENTO
dialogues.text: Have you ever been to Praia das Magas?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: Oh, you’re going to love it. I can’t wait for you to see it. It’s the most beautiful beach. Praia das Magas. Beach of the Apples.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Are there a lot of apple trees there?

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: None. It’s called “Apple Beach” because of the apple in the Bible, you know?

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: In Paradise. The temptation. The original sin.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: The Adam and Eve apple?

dialogues.speaker: BENTO
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s right.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: That’s insane. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: We are a very Catholic country, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARLINHOS, a 5 or 6 year old boy, comes from the woods ne the church, playing with a small shovel, picking up falle leaves.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Many, many years ago, at a time when the Barbarians dominated Portugal, there lived in Sintra a princess named Eufemia, who fell in love with a nice country boy. Carlinhos runs up the road, to an open area where the qua Church of Santa Eufemia is built.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Her father the King was a very tough, conservative man, and wouldn't allow the relationship with a commoner, so they had to stop seeing each other once and for all. Carlinhos looks at the simple church, white, with a coupl small green windows, the image of a female saint on tiles the side, and a cross at the very top. It’s strikingly beautiful in its simplicity. CARLINHOS’S MOTHER (0O.S.) Carlinhos!! Volta!! Carlinhos runs back towards his mother. We get closer to church, where Michel is standing outside, next to Tiago.  42. The back part of the church is all constructed in stone, old, with a garden and another small building in the same style.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: One day, the princess ran into the boy’s mother, who told her that the boy had been struck with a very painful, debilitating skin disease. The princess -—

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Ah! Voila! Michel waves. Jimmy and Frankie are walking up a dirt road, towards the church.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Bonjour! JOANA and JOAO, two Sintra locals, carrying a picnic bask and bottles of wine, walk arm in arm, a few steps ahead o them. Joana looks back, discreetly towards Frankie, and whispers something to her husband. Michel greets Frankie, two kisses.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL MICHEL
dialogues.text: Viens, chérie. Tiago est en Come, cherie. Tiago is train de nous raconter telling us the story of the l'histoire de Sainte- Saint. Euphémie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: What a beautiful church, so simple.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I told you!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Bonjour, Tiago!

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: Bonjour, Senhora. I was telling them that during the time of the Barbarians--

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: It’s okay, Tiago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a Frankie) La jolie princesse s’était éprise d’un gargon du peuple mais le Roi son pére lui interdit de le revoir. Le jeune homme tomba alors gravement malade.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: (to Tiago) Just keep going.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: The disease spread 43.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: (to Frankie) The good princess fell in love with a commoner and her father forbid their affair. The boy got sick. all over - the boy’s body, his whole skin, was full of horrible, bloody sores. The princess went to see the boy, against her father’s orders, and brought him here, where they used to come to see the view. She washed him in the waters from the fountain and-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: His skin went back to normal immediately.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: No. Not immediately. He felt better slowly. It took him days. Arms first, then the legs, the face and then--; the whole body. It was a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: And people still come here to wash themselves in this miraculous water.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: They do, because the water is said to cure people of all maladies. Frankie knows what is going on in their minds.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Where’s the fountain? Tiago points to a sign to the side. Impatient, Frankie starts to walk the other way, down tow the woods.
Frankie! S'il te plait.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Frankie! A thought disturbs Frankie; she stops midway and turns ba to respond to Jimmy and Michel.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: The two of you together... I can’t take it. worst combination!

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Please?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (to Michel) Leave it. it’s the Michel puts his hands in prayer, imploring.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Frankie, please.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Arréte ton cirque, Michel.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Ce ne sont pas trois gouttes d’eau qui vont te faire du mal, Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Je ne crois pas a4 ces conneries.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Ne traite pas ga de conneries.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: D’accord, pardon. Mais s’il te plait arréte, 1a. Et arréte de prendre cet air accablé. Je n’en peux plus de cette téte d’enterrement. Comme si celle de Jimmy ne me suffisait pas. Regarde-le.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Michel. You're making a scene.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: It doesn't hurt, Frankie - to splash a little water.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I don't believe in this shit.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Don't call it ‘shit’.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm sorry. But please stop. And stop looking so miserable. I can't put up with the sad face. I have enough of that with Jimmy already. Look at him.  20 45. They turn to look at Jimmy, who stands lost in his own thoughts, not listening.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE FRANKIE
dialogues.text: (a Michel) (to Michel) Je suis 4 bout, 1a. I almost can't bear it.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL MICHEL
dialogues.text: Sois plus douce, Frankie. Be kind, Frankie. This is not Tout ne tourne pas autour de all about you. toi.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ah bon? Isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I’m going to ask you both a favor: at least pretend that you accept my fate. For the sake of this trip, for the family, for today, please. Frankie turns around, and goes into the woods, leaving th three men alone in the churchyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie walks through the woods. The sunlight draws geome patterns on the ground, while playing a sometimes bright mostly dark game on Frankie’s face. What could be jarring a calming effect on her. She pauses to enjoy the sunlight her face for a moment, and then keeps going. A BIG FAMILY OF LOCALS is having a picnic in an open area surrounded by a fertile garden, and connected to a modest Quinta that sits on the edge of the woods. There is a pic table set up under a leafy grape arbor, and a fire burnin a portable barbecue pit in the center. It’s a happy event with KIDS running around while ADULTS sit around the tabl eating a big family meal. Among them, the couple from the previous scene. Joana's face brightens up, and she sees something and pokes ANTONIA, her aunt, next to her.

dialogues.speaker: JOANA JOANA
dialogues.text: Nao te disse? I told you. The woman recognizes Frankie immediately:

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: Irma Aline. Sister Aline.

dialogues.speaker: JOANA
dialogues.text: Frangoise Cremont.  21 46. Frankie nods and smiles, acknowledging their presence, an tries to keep going, but now the whole family is looking her. Antonia pours some wine in a glass.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: Madame Cremont! She offers the glass to Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: I'm a big fan.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: (jokingly) You must have good taste in movies.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: I know you from the TV.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. Let me guess-—

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: Os Arquivos do Vaticano.

dialogues.speaker: JOANA
dialogues.text: The Vatican Files. Frankie raises her glass.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Os Arquivos do Vaticano forever!

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIA
dialogues.text: It’s my mother’s birthday. She’d be happy if you can make a toast with us? She really identifies with your character Sister Aline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the simple church, Michel is sitting, his eyes clo in prayer, in front of the small statue of a Saint. Jimmy stands in the rear of the church, watching Michel. takes hold of the back of a bench, uncomfortable.  22 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiago stands at the side of the church, checking his phon

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don’t really believe in all this, do you? Tiago smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Senhor. Whatever helps can’t hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I guess that’s right. Tiago pulls out a pack of cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: You mind?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Not at all. Tiago offers one from the pack to Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: No, no, thank you. Tiago lights up, and they stand together, quietly.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Are you married, Tiago?

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: Yes, I am. I have a wife and a son. They live in Braga, in the North.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I see. You’re separated then?

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Just for five months a year. I come down here for the tourist season.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I imagine that can be difficult.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: To be honest, it is. It’s very hard. My wife, she’s like my police. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love her, but she doesn’t even like me sitting next to another woman. You can imagine what it’s like when I’m here in Sintra.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: That's why I look so tired today. I went out to dinner with a friend last night, another guide, and when I called my wife later to say “goodnight, I love you”, she already knew where I’d been, what I drank, and who else was at the restaurant. It was incredible. We stayed up for hours on the phone, which is not good for my business. I have to be alert, and the days are not short, you know? Tiago takes a long drag.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sometimes I don’t even know why I stay married. Jimmy just looks at Tiago. He doesn’t know how to respond

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Seflor. It’s not to bother you. I am good. I am fine. Shall we move on? I will go see about your friend now, make sure we didn’t lose him. This is not really a place for tourists, and it’s quite difficult to find the spot of the “miraculous waters.” Tiago walks away, leaving Jimmy alone with his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie sits on the bench, next to ERMELINDA, a beautiful older lady in her 80's, surrounded by the whole family, w move around loudly, rearranging themselves around the two women . Ermelinda leans over to Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J'ai vu votre photo dans le magazine. Celle qu’ils ont prise 4 l’hdépital. Vous vous étes battue comme une lionne, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: ERMELINDA
dialogues.text: I saw your photo in the Magazine. The photo in the hospital. You fought a tough battle, Madame. Frankie’s doesn’t know how to react to her comment; she smiles, with no conviction. A young man, FELIPE, her great nephew, stands in front of crowd with a camera, a real camera, ready to take a photo

dialogues.speaker: FELIPE
dialogues.text: Tia, um pouquinho mais pra direita. Isso. Gustavo, fica parado!

dialogues.speaker: FELIPE
dialogues.text: Auntie, go to the right. Gustavo, stay put! Ermelinda continues her whispers to Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: ERMELINDA
dialogues.text: Ma meilleure amie a vécu la méme chose. C’était une femme d’une force exceptionnelle, mais je 1’ai quand méme perdue. Vous, vous avez gagné. Vous étes 1a. Vous étes une dame intrépide.

dialogues.speaker: ERMELINDA
dialogues.text: My best friend went through the same thing. She was a tough woman, but I lost her. You won. You're here. You must be very brave. (screaming, to everyone) Feliz aniversdrio, Mama!

dialogues.speaker: FELIPE
dialogues.text: Prontos?! The family raise their glasses, filled with wine, and sta singing in Portuguese.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY MEMBERS
dialogues.text: Parabens a voce Nessa data querida--

dialogues.speaker: ERMELINDA
dialogues.text: N&o, nado! Para. S6 um momento.

dialogues.speaker: ERMELINDA
dialogues.text: No, no! Stop. Stop! Just a moment. The crowd quiets down to listen to the Old Lady.  24 50.

dialogues.speaker: ERMELINDA ERMELINDA
dialogues.text: A maravilhosa Frangoise To the stunning Frangoise Cremont, que fez o meu Cremont, who made my 88th octagésimo oitavo aniversdrio birthday a more beautiful ficar mais alegre. one.

dialogues.speaker: ERMELINDA ERMELINDA
dialogues.text: (a Frankie) (to Frankie) A vous, Frangoise Cremont, To you, Frangoise Cremont, qui avez rendu mon 88éme who made my 88th birthday a anniversaire encore plus more beautiful one. beau!

dialogues.speaker: ERMELINDA
dialogues.text: (to all) A la santé! Everybody is happy, cheering and toasting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A la santé! Para sua satde! Frangoise! And they start singing again.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: Parabens a voce Nessa data querida Muitas felicidades Muitos anos de vida Hoje € dia de festa Cantam as nossas almas Para a menina Ermelinda Uma salva de palmas! There’s applause and whistles all around. It’s a loud, me and happy family moment. Frankie leans over, and gives th old lady a kiss. Felipe takes a picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few SURFERS float lazily on top of their boards in the As a wave rises, Pedro swims with fast strokes in order t ride it. As the surf breaks, Pedro picks up speed with hi board, conquering the wave and gracefully riding it all t way to the sand. Maya sits on a towel on the white sand scribbling in her notebook.  25 51. She raises her eyes, and sees Pedro, his face, hair and b dripping sea water. He tucks the boogie board into the sa in front of Maya.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Maya dives into the ocean with a boogie board. She braves breaking wave with fast, strong strokes against the curre swimming all the way past the surf. Maya floats in the ocean, on the board, blue skies above a restful moment before the waves crash on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ian, still in his running outfit, comes from inside with coffees. He approaches Sylvia, waiting outside, and she g one of the two cups.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Wait. I think it’s the other one.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Your coffee.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: The cappuccino is for me.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Mine is with skim milk. Sylvia offers him her cup, so they can switch.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Wait?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Tan.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I’m confused now.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: For God's sake, sweetheart, you just ran four miles. A little fat won't kill you. She picks up his cup, and makes him take hers, a little forcefully.  52. They walk up the street, Sylvia’s cell phone rings. She l at it, and tries to disguise her eagerness to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Another letting agent? Sylvia is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Look for it, Ian, and you shall find it. Upset, she rushes to get away from him. He has to pick up pace to catch up with her fast steps.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Don’t be such an ass. Maya told me.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: She told you what?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: She told me. You don’t have to hide from me anymore, Sylvia.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know what she told you because there’s nothing to tell. And why would you ask her, anyway? Why would you involve her? It’s not some Machiavellian scheme. I’m just looking.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: That means you’re thinking.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: You can’t be that surprised.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I’m not surprised, but it makes me sad. What we’re going through... I think it’s normal.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I don’t want normal.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Where’s Maya anyway?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I’m sure she went to the beach. She wanted us all to go yesterday.  26 53.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: The beach??

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Alone?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Why did you let her?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: She didn’t ask me.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I hope it’s safe.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I told her not to go very far.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: She has a mind of her own, our girl.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Oh yes, she does. Ian puts his arm around Sylvia.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Like her mother. They walk up the road in each other’s arm, a romantic cou on vacation for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilene walks fast, ahead of Gary, who struggles a little trying to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You're walking so fast. We’re not in New York City, you know. You'd think you’re trying to get away from me.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I’m just a little thrown, that’s all.  54.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Ilene, please, slow down. Gary stops, giving Ilene little option but to do so as we

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen to me. I’ve spent the last ten years of my life going wherever work took me. I used to get so excited about going to a new place -— Iceland, Patagonia, Vancouver! - but now I’m tired. Not tired, but I have a strange feeling. Emptiness. I’m home, the sun goes down, and... I think I just feel lonely. Do you ever feel that way?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: No. Not really. I like being by myself. I always have, even when I was a kid. I get home after two months away, and I’m happy to be by myself. I have my books, my magazines, my kitchen, my bed, my friends when I want them. I feel content.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I guess I don’t. I’m not content. I want change. I don’t want to just continue like it’s all going to last forever. I want to start something new. With you. New for both of us. We have to admit we are in the middle, Ilene, or past the middle. It’s not really the time to coast, is it?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Gary, you just need to make your own movie. Ilene proceeds, starts to walk again.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No, that’s not what I need. Maybe I will, maybe I won't. They approach the end of this green, lush walkway, and suddenly they’re in the middle of a road, where cars and Tuk Tuk’s, ride by.  27 55.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I’m ready to settle down, Ilene. I love you. I love being with you. You know I don’t care about marriage, that’s not important to me. But being with you is. It is important to me. And Water Mill could be the answer. There’s a lot of space there. I could turn the garage into a new studio for me, and then you could have the second bedroom inside all for yourself. I would knock before entering. I promise. What do you say? A MEGA TOURIST BUS invades the screen, and stops right ah of Gary and Ilene. It’s door open, with a mechanized, lou oomph! Ilene’s attention veers towards the CROWD of TOURISTS, wh descend upon the road, happy and excited. A moment later, she finds herself in the middle of the cr which seems to have multiplied itself. Ilene lets herself be taken away by the movement of the crowd. Gary looks out, but soon he can’t see her anymore.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Ilene? Ilene? Ilene!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michel and Jimmy walk through a sunny area in the park, i the middle of a conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: .+.jJust as the sun rises every morning, and the night comes at the end of the day, I was certain Frankie and I were going to be together forever. So when one day she told me she was leaving, I wondered, how is it possible? When we got married, I believed in those vows. ‘Til death do us part, and all of that.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You always were a good Catholic.  56.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: You know, until today, I hadn't been inside a church in a long time. But yes, I was raised ina very Catholic family. They continue walking.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Frankie and I were so young. And I was scared. I didn’t know if anything was going to work out. The restaurant. Frankie. My relationship to my own family. It’s hard to remember now - we remember mostly the fun, the exciting parts - but it was scary to be young, no?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: You never met my father, did you?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: He was tough. He was in the Resistance, you know, a real hero. And a real Catholic. Marriage for me was a life saver.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: That’s not very sexy, is it? A woman wants to feel desired, not needed for survival.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Not just women. We do too. But at that time, I didn’t know that. I couldn't imagine my life without Frankie. And yet, today I know that her leaving was the best thing that ever happened to me. I met Thierry. I finally allowed myself to fall in love with a man.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: That must have felt good.  57.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Times were different, you know. The way I was brought up and everything. It wasn’t easy for me, but Thierry was very persistent.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I remember the day you called to tell Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Frankie acted so shocked, I almost gave her an Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: That was not a performance. I was there.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: But, please. She should’ve known.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: She didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Amazing how people sometimes choose not to see what’s right in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: She told me she never knew, which means that your performance must have been very convincing. You should have got the Oscar. Michel laughs, then continues.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: She was very worried about Paul. Thierry and I. How it would affect him.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: She’s still very worried about Paul, but not because of you. She can’t see him as anything but a small child in need of constant guidance and protection.
