Kids have to be left to find their own path. Certainly my daughter has. Sylvia never looked at me for any direction, even when she was a little girl.  58. They pause. A quiet moment of reflection between them.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I liked Thierry, by the way. I really did. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe the restaurant. Late nights. Other men. Alcohol. We gave it our best.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I know that. They approach a small chapel, where Tiago is waiting for them. He steps forward, and greets the two men with his p expertise.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: The Capela Manuelina was built by Jeronimo monks in the sixteenth century. This used to be a sacred space for meditation and reclusi--

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: (to Tiago) Just a minute, my dear. (to Jimmy ) Jimmy, after Frankie...

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: ...-things might change. After. If there’s somebody, and I hope there will be-

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Michel.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Life takes turns, you know. Things change.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I don’t know what “after Frankie” means. There’s no “after Frankie” for me. There’s some tension, and Tiago feels it might be better leave the two men alone.  28 59.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: I’m going to talk to the guards, and see if we can get inside.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: Let’s go, Jimmy. Jimmy doesn’t seem very interested.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m told there’s some beautiful Arabic tile inside.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: (to Michel) No. You go. I'll catch up with you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary is walking alone, when he recognizes someone in fron and picks up speed.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Frankie! Frankie is walking alone right ahead. She turns, as Gary approaches, his right hand extended, greeting her.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bonjour, Frankie, Frangoise. I’m Gary. I’m here with Ilene. We arrived this morning.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ah! You're the friend.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: She told you about me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: No, she didn’t. My husband did. I guess you met him earlier. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Such a pleasure to meet you. Frankie and Gary walk along the road, side by side, makin small talk.  60.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm working with Ilene on Star Wars. I’m the second unit DP.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: That must be a lot of work.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I’m tired, and thankful for this break.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: First time in Sintra?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: First time in Portugal. We have been shooting for almost a month now, and when Ilene told me you were here, I said ‘let’s go’. I'ma big fan, you know.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I’m a fan of Ilene’s. She’s been a good friend.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: We met on another film we did together. The Void. I was the Principal DP on that. We’ve been hanging out, you know.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure what that means.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I love Ilene.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ah. That’s something.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Frankie, Ilene says. May I call you Frankie?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: That’s what my friends call me.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You look even better in person, you know. Do people tell you that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You're being kind.  61.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No, it’s true. You know, I wanted to talk with you about something, if we can find the right time. I have a film project that I want to direct.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Your first time directing?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Yes, well, no. But my first feature. I’ve been thinking about it for a long time. And I’ve shot over 18 films for other people. I’m ready to start, you know. And I think you and I share a taste ina certain kind of cinema. It’s about an opera singer who loses her voice.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ha. That’s funny.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I think you’d be perfect for it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I can’t sing.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: But that’s it! She loses her voice. It’s almost like silent film acting, and I can’t think of anyone more expressive for the role. Like Greta Garbo.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Or Fatty Arbuckle. Gary laughs, uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Can I can send you the script?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: If you’d like. When are you thinking of shooting this?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: It’s not going to happen now. I need a year, at least, to prepare. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we’re going to collaborate I think it’s better to be up front with you, it’s going to take time to get it together. You know the business. I’d say realistically it will be a year, a year and a half, before we start shooting.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I see. Frankie takes a deep breath. They walk side by side in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You know, Frankie. I’m going to take time off to work on this film. I have a house in Water Mill, that’s just under two hours from New York, it’s a beautiful place. I've invited Ilene to come live with me. Don’t you think it would be a good idea for her to settle down a little bit? Not travel so much. Not work so much on projects she doesn’t really care about?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Does it matter what I think?

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: You know her well.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: But does it matter? If you’ve invited her, then you should know. Ilene is the kind of woman who'll tell you straight to your face what she thinks. No bullshit, Ilene. And no bullshitters. She doesn’t have time for people who aren’t very real, very sincere, you know? That's why I like her. Gary doesn’t know quite how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now if you’1ll excuse me, I’m going to go look for my son. I haven’t seen him since the morning, and this was meant to be a family vacation.  29 63. She walks away, leaving Gary alone among the trees and th silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cliffs at the end of the beach. Maya, wearing only a T-shirt over her wet beach clothes, hikes/climbs the tric part of a ledge. She places one foot on a rock, while one hand tries to hold on to a higher mark on the ledge. She makes sure the one foot is firm on the rock, while lookin for a safe step for the other foot. She climbs up for a second, but not sure of her next step, strides back down. That’s when a helping hand enters frame. Pedro extends his arm and pulls Maya up. As she climbs, s steps with the wrong foot, and falls into his arms, clums They smile, a bit disconcerted. Maya and Pedro walk hand in hand on this rocky path high at the end of the beach. They are away but not far from t sand, surrounded by the ocean. They stop to look at the v the long golden sand beach, and on the other end, a rocky cliff crowned with small, charming white houses, typical Portuguese.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Is that still Sintra?

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: That’s Colares, actually.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: It’s so pretty.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: I knew you would like it. If you like, I can buy you a postcard. Maya faces the view, breathing in the moment. Pedro comes from behind, and puts his arms around her. She holds his arms, welcoming the gesture.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I used to come here with my parents and my sister every summer. My whole life, until I was thirteen.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: And then what happened.  64.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: My parents got divorced. My vacations were divided between time with Mom, then time with Dad, and there was no time left for this Apple Beach anymore. A SEAGULL flies overhead, and dives into the water. A wav crashes in the ocean down below.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But then I met Bento in Lisboa last year. We played football against each other in a national tournament. His school won, but we became friends after, and he invited me to visit him in Sintra. Pedro turns Maya around. They’re face to face, and she gi him a kiss. Pedro smiles, happily surprised, and soon aft they kiss again, this time a long, slow one, both discove the pleasure of each other’s mouths.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have a confession. The real story of this Apple Beach has nothing to do with Adam and Eve. I’m sorry. Can I tell you?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: It’s okay. If you'd like.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: They say that the Ribeira River, over there, used to carry down apples from the farms in Colares all the way to the coast, and they would end on the beach down here. But the thing is, I’ve never seen one single apple tree in Colares, so I don’t believe this story. There aren't any apple farms in Colares. For Maya, he talks too much. She kisses him again. After another long moment, he pulls away, and looks at he with near wonder.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When can I see you again?  30

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: (laughing) But I’m still here.
I know, but I miss you already. She smiles, happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 Paul is walking alone on the road, appreciating the view enjoying a peaceful moment. He carries the beaten down bouquet of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Paul! He turns around, and sees his mother rushing down to be w him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Paul. Attends. J’arrive.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Paul. Wait. I'm coming. He opens his arm, and embraces his mother when she comes close. They hold each other for a long moment, strongly. conversation between them is all in French.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Tiens, c’est pour toi. Elles sont un peu défraichies, mais bon. He hands her the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ca tombe bien, moi aussi.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Allez, ga mérite quand méme un selfie. He pulls out his phone.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ah non, tu as vu ma téte?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: These are for you. They've seen better days, I know.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: That's perfect, so have I.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Let's take a picture.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Oh no, not with this hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arréte. Tu es super belle aujourd'hui.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Tu dis ga pour me faire plaisir.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Non, c’est la vérité. Tu es magnifique. Tiens, tourne-toi par 1a, avec le paysage derriére nous. 66.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: C'mon. You look so beautiful today.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You're just saying that.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: But you do. You look wonderful. Come here, turn this way. With the view behind us. Accepting the compliment, Frankie combs her hair with her hands quickly, before positioning herself for a photo. Pa puts his arm around her, and takes a selfie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: On en prend un autre.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: One more. She changes her angle slightly. Another click.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Envoie-le a Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: A vos ordres. They start walking, side by side.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Je n’ai pas trés bien dormi.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Encore te migraines?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Atroces. C’est de pire en pire.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Prends te cachets.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Mais je le prends.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Send it to Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Right now.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I didn't sleep very well.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Headaches again?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Awful. They're getting worse.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Take the pills.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Augment la dose.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ce n’est pas comme ga que ¢a marche. Il faut que j’en parle au Dr. Bernhard. Tu sais, ils sont déja trés forts.

dialogues.speaker: _ PAUL
dialogues.text: Et alors? A ce stade... 67.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Take more.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: It's not like that. I have to talk to Dr. Bernhard. They're very strong, you know.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So what? At this point. Paul talked without thinking, and his comment hits Franki the wrong way. Her eyes tear up, and she looks away, tryi to hide them from her son. But he knows.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Excuse-moi Maman. vraiment désolé. Je suis

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Mais il n’y a pas de quoi.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: C’est juste que je ne veux pas que tu souffres.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Tu as raison. A ce stade, qu’est-ce que ga peut faire?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: En tout cas, tu as l’air reposée.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Je suis payée pour faire semblant. Frankie takes her bracelet off. before she offers it to him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Tiens. Je voudrais te le donner.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Maman. I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Nothing to be sorry about.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I just don't want you to feel any pain.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You're right. At this point, who cares?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Anyway, you do look rested.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I'm good at pretending. Paul notices her admiring it,

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Here. I want you to have this. She pushes the shiny bracelet into his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Je n’en veux pas. He tries to give it back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Il vaut au moins vingt mille euros. Si je te le donne maintenant, tu n’auras pas de droits a payer plus tard. Mets-le 4 l’abri dans un coin sir et comme ga d’ici quelques années, le tour est joué, c’est a toi. Personne n’y verra que du feu.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oui mais je n’en veux pas.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Il plaira peut-étre 4 ta future femme.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Avant ga il faudrait déja que je me trouve une copine, tu ne crois pas?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: C'est cher la vie 4 New York, tu sais.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: J'y vais avec un trés bon boulot, comme je te l’ai déja dit. Je sais que ga te dépasse, mais je gagne extrémement bien ma vie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Je sais. Et je n’approuve pas.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Que tu approuves ou pas, ¢a m’est égal. 68.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I don't want this.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: It's worth at least twenty thousand. If you take it now, there won't be any taxes later. Just put it away somewhere very safe. Then in a few years, voila, it's yours. No one will know the difference.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I don't want it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Maybe your future wife will like it.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'd first need to find a girlfriend, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: New York can be very expensive, you know.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I have a good job. You know that. I know it’s hard for you to believe, but I make a lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I know. I don't approve.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I don't care if you approve. She forcefully hands him the bracelet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bon allez. Prends-le. 69.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Here. Take it. Paul holds the bracelet, finally, but looks at it without much care.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Il y a autre chose dont it faut qu’on discute. Cette histoire de trust dont a parlé Sylvia. L’argent, c’est ton domaine. De quoi il s'agit?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Pour ga il faudrait qu’on prenne rendez-vous avec un avocat, quelqu’un qui maitrise vraiment le sujet. Ca ne se régle pas comme ga et on n’est pas obligés de parler de droits de succession maintenant. Si on est en vacances c’est justement pour oublier tout ga.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: C’est pourtant vité réglé. Tout ce que j’ai, c’est l’‘appartement de Paris. Je l’ai déja mis en vente, et j’ai l’intention de léguer ce que je vais en tirer au Conservatoire.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ah bon? Tu leur en fais don? Et Jimmy, il le sait déja?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Mais, oui. Bien sir. Toi, tu n’as pas besoin de moi. Tu me l‘'as déja parfaitement fait comprendre. Jimmy s’est trés bien débrouillé, il a mis ce qu’il lui faut de cdté. Sylvia peut compter sur Ian. Je suis stire qu’il a gagné encore plus d’argent que toi.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: There's something else we need to talk about. This incorporating idea of Sylvia's. Money is your business. What is she talking about?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I think we should just set up a meeting with a lawyer, someone who really understands the situation. These things are complicated. We don't need to talk inheritance taxes while we're here. It's a vacation from all of that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Not much to talk about. All I have is the apartment in Paris. I've already put it on the market. I intend to donate the proceeds to the Conservatoire.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Really? You're giving it away? Does Jimmy know?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course. You don't need me. You've made that perfectly clear. And Jimmy's saved plenty from his own work. There's more than enough there. And Ian will take care of Sylvia. I'm sure he's made even more than you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sirement. Je ne suis pas en train de me plaindre, Maman. Je n’ai aucune envie de vivre a Paris. Si tu veux faire don de l’appartement, vas-y. Simplement... je suis surpris. Il vaut tant que ga de toute fagon?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: J’'en demande trois millions. Tu connais le quartier.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: A mon avis tu te trompes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ne me dis pas que je me trompe. Tu n’as pas a me rabaisser comme ga. Ca n’est vraiment pas nécessaire. Et ensuite le Conservatoire s'est engagé a créer une bourse Frangoise Cremont pour les apprentis comédiens.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ah d’accord...

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Je sais que c’est vaniteux de ma part. Mais c’est ga que je veux, et je prends mes dispostions en conséquence. J'ai besoin que tu t’assures qu’ils le feront bien. Tu peux me promettre de t’en occuper, Paul?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Qu’ils feront bien quoi?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Qu’ils créeront bel et bien cette bourse!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Non mais arréte, 1a! On dirait que tu parles d’une bande d’escrocs. 70.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'm sure. I'm not complaining, Maman. I don't want to live in Paris anyway. It's fine for you to give the apartment away. I'm just... I'm surprised. Is the apartment really worth that much money anyway?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I'm asking three million. You know the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I think you're mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Don't tell me I'm mistaken. Don't put me down like that. It's not necessary. It's not. And the school has promised they would set up a Frangoise Cremont Scholarship for young actors.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ah. I see.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: It's vanity, I know. But I want it, and I'm planning for it now. I need you to make sure they do it. Can you promise me that, Paul?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: They do what?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Set up the scholarship!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, please. They're not crooks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quant au reste, il n’y a pas grand-chose. Je le donne au fur et a mesure. 71.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: The rest, there's not much. I'm giving it away as I go. Paul looks at the bracelet again. This time, the light hi it’s precious stones, and it shines brighter: it seems to hold more value than just a few seconds before.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Tu as vu Ilene?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: C’est qui Ilene?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Mon amie Ilene. Elle est arrivée.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ilene. Celle dont tu parles tous le temps.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Oui. Mon amie chef-coiffeuse. Elle a énormement de talent. Et puis elle est maligne comme tout, et elle me fait rire. Je suis stire qu’elle te plairait.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Elle habite & New York... Frankie nods.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Et elle n’a pas de mec.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ah ga, je n’en sais rien. Mais elle est trés jolie. Elle est beaucoup plus jeune que moi.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Et comme par hasard elle débarque a Sintra en méme temps que nous.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Have you seen Ilene yet?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Who's Ilene.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: My friend Ilene. She's here.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ilene. The one you always talk about.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Yes. My hair stylist friend. She's so talented. Smart, she makes me laugh. I am sure you'd really like her.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She lives in New York.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And she's single.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Ah, that-- I don't know. But she's very pretty. She's much younger than me, you know.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And she happens to be in Sintra at the same time that we are here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elle traville en Espagne. C’est juste a cdté.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: C’était censé étre des vancances en famille!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Elle est sur le tournage du nouveau Star Wars. C’est énorme! Donc tu vois, quand je te dis qu’elle est douée... 72.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: She's working in Spain, around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: This was supposed to be a family vacation!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: She's on the new Star Wars movie. It's a major job. Shows you how good she is. All of a sudden, the bracelet feels heavy on Paul’s hand. He’s clearly very upset, and he tosses the bracelet up an down.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: C’est marrant. La plupart des méres trouvent que personne n’est jamais assez bien pour les fils.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Je ne sais pas de quelles méres tu parles. Pas la mienne en tout cas. Du moment qu’il était un homme et pas juif, elle était ravie. Ca lui était méme égal qu’il soit homo. They pause, angry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Paul, toute ta vie je t’ai toujours donné tout ce que tu as voulu, et pourtant tu n’es jamais content de rien. Rien ne te suffit jamais. Aucune femme. Aucun homme. Aucune mére. Aucun pére.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Funny. For most mothers, there is never anyone good enough for their sons.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I don't know what mothers you are talking about. Not my mother. As long as he was a man and he wasn't a Jew, she was perfectly happy. She didn't even care if he was a homosexual.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Paul, I've given you everything you've ever wanted your whole life, and yet you are never satisfied with anything. Nothing is enough for you. No woman. No man. No mother. No father. In one quick gesture, Paul throws the bracelet away, far down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Paul?! Mais tu es malade??

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Paul?! Are you crazy??  31 73. Paul turns around and walks away from his mom, furious. Frankie takes off, goes running down the hill, dropping t bouquet of flowers behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul is still fuming, walking with firm, fast steps, when runs into Sylvia.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: There you are.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m late. I’m meeting Ian for lunch in town.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I just came from talking with Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: The level of manipulation is beyond anything I can fully explain. And by the way, she’s selling the Paris apartment, so don’t get your hopes up. She’s getting all her ducks in a row, as the Americans say. You knew she would leave nothing to chance.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: What do you mean she’s selling the apartment?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It’s already on the market, and she’s made up her mind. She's leaving everything she’s got to the Conservatoire, which is not much, it turns out, besides the apartment. The news stops Sylvia cold in her tracks. She leans on th ancient, moss covered rail wall that accompanies the road

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Seriously? That’s absurd.  32 74.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She worked her whole life. She can do whatever she wants with her money. And what she wants is to be remembered. She’s setting up the Frangoise Cremont Scholarship Fund for poor and needy actresses. That’s what she wants. I’m sorry her death won’t help you leave your boring husband, but I quite like the idea. Sylvia picks up her pace, walking fast away from Paul.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Sylvia. Sylvia!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilene walks by herself in the woods. This is a more primitive, more chaotic part of the hills. The trees are taller, their canopies denser, and the light struggles to reach the ground. Ilene allows herself to get lost in the colors, the shades and light of nature. A sound brings Ilene’s attention back to the earth. She l to the side, behind a bush, and sees a woman on all fours sweeping fallen leaves around with her hands. It’s Frankie, combing through the foliage, looking for something. A shiny point a few feet away makes her franti for a second, until she realizes it’s nothing but an ordi rock. She looks up, and sees Ilene.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: What did you lose now, Frankie darling? Ilene extends her hand, but Frankie isn’t ready to get up yet.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: If you stumble upon a Bulgari bracelet, it’s mine.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Emeralds, rubies and diamonds. Ilene goes down on the ground and looks around her, and s does Frankie. They can’t find anything.  75. They’re both on all fours, now face to face, and they sta laughing.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: You're joking.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: My stupid son.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: It’s the only one I have. Help me up here. I’ve looked everywhere already. Ilene gets up, and extends her hand. Frankie holds it, an she gets up, she falls into Ilene’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Oh Ilene. It’s so good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: It’s good to see you. Frankie’s face looks more pale than normal. Her eyes lose sight, her lips lose their color. She feels suddenly dizz

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I’m okay. Frankie tries to stay up, but her legs get weak.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Help me. Ilene rushes to hold her friend, but as she does, Frankie starts to fall down.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Frankie!  33 76. Ilene still tries to hold her up, but once she notices it serious, and Frankie is actually falling, she lets her to ground, carefully, holding her head so it doesn’t hit anything.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Frankie! Frankie lies on the ground, as her eyes roll back, and th muscles in her body jerk rhythmically for a second. Ilene stands back, desperate, unsure of what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ian and Sylvia sit at a restaurant in the city of Sintra. He’s served a salad by the WAITER, while Sylvia picks on bread and butter at the table.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: You're not going to eat?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I’m not very hungry. Ian digs into his meal.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll have a glass of wine. Waiter! The Waiter comes back, while Sylvia is looking at the men

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the waiter) A glass of Planalto, por favor. The waiter takes the menu, and leaves. Ian looks down at his plate, and sticks his fork into a b chunk of lettuce.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Regardless of what I feel, and of what I think you feel, we have a home and an amazing daughter, and... maybe it’s my personality, I don’t know... I didn’t grow up like you. All of you. I don’t have the same expectations maybe. I’d like to think that our life together, our family, is the most important thing.  77. Sylvia wasn’t expecting this. She takes a sip of Ian’s wh wine. IAN (CONT’D) Of course I can fantasize once ina while what my life would be like if I had made different choices. That’s normal. It’s human. But actually going through a divorce? It hasn't crossed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Never?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Well, I can’t say the same. They sit in a silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: So then you must know that there’s only one ‘ground’ for divorce under British law, which is that the marriage has irretrievably broken down. Five facts may constitute this ground: adultery, unreasonable behavior, two years separation, if both parties consent; five years separation, if only one party consents, and two years desertion. Ian pauses, and eats a small bite of his meal. IAN (CONT’D) I've been faithful to you, Sylvia. It would take a long, very expensive legal battle to try and prove unreasonable behavior on my part, which I think would be your only possible path.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I never thought about getting into a battle with you.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: So I’m glad we’re having this conversation, because I wouldn't just let you go, Sylvia. You’d have to take me to a court of law, that’s what it would take.  78.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: God, you did more research than I did.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Of course I did. I called a lawyer. What do you expect me to do? He made some calculations for me.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Calculations!

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I like to be prepared. You must have made calculations, yourself, but this is what we came up with. In the unlikely event that you are granted a decree Absolute, since you don’t have a salary, your alimony would get you, according to our calculations, a one bedroom in Upper Edmonton, maybe a two bed/one bath in Lower Edmonton. The Waiter arrives with Sylvia's glass of white wine.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: That’s where Maya’s kick boxing instructor lives.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Is she the Bolivian?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Then, maybe. That would make sense. I hear Lower is very popular among South American immigrants. Sylvia takes a sip of her wine, and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: I’m going to go.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: You don’t want to go with me to pick up Maya?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: No. I want to go see the Regaleira.  34 79.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: You want to go see the Regaleira. I see. What is the Regaleira, may I ask?

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIA
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: No, that’s right. You’re right, Sylvia. It doesn’t matter. Sylvia turns around, and heads out. Ian, disappointed, pi up her glass full of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilene has her arm around Frankie, as they walk out of the woods.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we call a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I’m fine, Ilene.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I was down on my knees for so long, when I got up I just felt faint for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: You didn’t just faint, sweetie. You had a seizure.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Was it really?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Yes. You scared me to death.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: No. It’s just that I had no idea what to do. Ilene lets go of Frankie, but keeps an eye on her.  80. They walk out of the woods, and into the road.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: You sure you’re okay now?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Yes. I just feel a little cold. Don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Let me take you to your hotel.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: It’s not far, I think. It’s a narrow road, and a SMALL GROUP of HIKERS come walk from the opposite direction, Ilene and Frankie get squeez on the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Has this happened before?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I have one of these every other day now.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: But I thought you were fine.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I was. After the treatment, I had two years completely cancer free. I went back to work, and it was great. I made two films, back to back, in England and in France.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: You told me you were exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Yes, but only because it was a long shoot, the one in Bath, and we had to be outdoors in the winter. It wasn’t easy, but it was wonderful. And I felt fine.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: And you did the series after?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Just one episode. They brought me back for one episode. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was supposed to be quick and easy, but I suddenly started to feel nauseous. I knew there was something going on, so I was reluctant to go see my doctor. I finished the work. And then I went to see him. Ilene blanches, feeling bad news about to hit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t want to go into all the details, but the cancer has spread, it’s everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Oh, Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: They don’t think I’1l see the New Year. Ilene looks around her, the nature and the skies, looking something to say, but she can’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The difficult part for me is seeing people cry, so please don’t cry. I wanted you to come here, because I want you to meet my family. I want us to have a good time, which for me now means just time together. Ilene throws her arm around Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I’m going to miss you terribly.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I know you will. Ilene squeezes her even tighter.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Are you still cold?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I’m okay.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Do you have any idea where we are? Frankie looks around the road, trying to find her way.  35 82.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh no. Why did I trust you? Frankie laughs. They’ve been through this before.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I have no sense of direction! A Tuk Tuk passes by, noisily, with no passenger. Frankie it and immediately makes a gesture for it to stop.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie and Ilene ride on the back of the Tuk Tuk through roads of Sintra. It goes fast, and it’s not the most comfortable vehicle... but they laugh when they have to h on to each other, as the Tuk Tuk goes into a sharp turn. Around them, the lush mountains of Sintra, its exotic palaces, its sublime tiled walls and its crumbling old houses. Frankie and Ilene have to talk loudly to be heard.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I met your fiancé.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Fiancé? Did he say that??

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: He says he wants to marry you.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Oh God. Frankie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: And he wants me to be in his movie. He’s going to give me a script.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Damn Gary. I’m sorry, Frankie. I told him not to do that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I told him I would read it, but it better be the starring role!  83.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Of course it is. He adores Frangoise Cremont. He really has seen all your movies.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: He has a lot of plans, this Gary.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: He’s a sweet guy, actually. We’ve had a lot of fun together. And I think the script will be good. He’s deeper than he seems, believe it or not.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: But you know he’s not the right one for you, Ilene. You must.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: But is there ‘the right one’ for me?

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Of course there is.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I feel like I’ve been looking my whole life!

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: “Trouve avant de chercher."” Ilene looks at her, not following.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Find it before you look for it.” It’s something Jimmy says. One of his famous quotes. Paul Valery. Or Breton, I think. The annoying noise of the mechanized three-wheeled taxi accompanies the beautiful ride.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Trouve avant de chercher."”

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: “Trouve avant de chercher."”  36 37 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gary walks down a remote, long road, alone, oblivious to everything around him. An OLD PORTUGUESE MAN walks by with his DOG, and as they by, the dog barks at Gary, bringing him back to the momen

dialogues.speaker: OLD PORTUGUESE MAN
dialogues.text: (to his dog) Quieto! Nao faga isso. (to Gary) Desculpe. Gary smiles politely, as the Old Man and the dog pass by. And now, with the dog’s bark far away, there is a strong silence surrounding Gary. He can hear the trees move, and wind, with piercing clarity. He is alone with himself in beautiful place, in Sintra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilene comes out of the house, onto the terrace. She takes the view of the lush valley below, a moment on her own to reflect on the tough news of the day.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ilene! It’s Gary, coming towards her, from the front gate of the Quinta. As he approaches her, Ilene walks towards him and, unexpectedly, she falls into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Oh, baby. Gary, surprised by her emotions, tightens his embrace.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, honey, sweet girl. Don’t worry. It’s okay. It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: It’s not...

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: Shhh...You don’t need to say anything.  85.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: When I came here... I wasn’t expecting so much.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I know. Me either. This place is really more to dream than to talk about. She looks at him with compassion.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know if it’s the mountain air, or these beautiful surroundings, I don’t know... but I realized today that love is all that matters. Not money. Not jobs, or movies. Or even companionship. I know it’s cliché, but for the first time I understand it’s only love that matters. Ilene listens intently. This is turning out differently t she expected.

dialogues.speaker: GARY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m going to leave, Ilene.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: But we still have a couple days off.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I know we do, but I’1l stay in Lisbon for a night or two. It’s supposed to be a great town.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Gary, I’m sorry-

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: There’s no need to apologize. My feelings for you... if it’s not reciprocal, it’s silly to pretend. I’m too old for that. Besides, I understand how much you value your independence. Stay here and enjoy your friends. That’s what you came here for.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Gary, when you shoot your film, I’1l come work on it.  38 39 86.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: No, I don’t think that’s a good idea anymore. I hope you understand.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Oh. Of course I do. I understand. Gary turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: GARY
dialogues.text: I should go pack. I have a car coming soon. He goes into the house, leaving Ilene alone on the terrac INT. QUINTA DE SAO THIAGO/FRANKIE & JIMMY’S SUITE - DAY 3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In her hotel room, Frankie is sleeping. Her pale white sk barely covering the veins below, she looks fragile, vulnerable, and so different than she has throughout. Jimmy sits in a chair by the bed, watching her closely, listening to every movement, every breath. After a long moment, he stands, and starts to take off hi clothes. He carefully hangs his pants on the back of a ch then his shirt on a hanger. He goes to the bed, and gets in beside Frankie. Then he turns, and puts his arms around her. She feels his body close to hers, and turns towards him. They start to make love, quietly, passionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilene walks along the road.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ilene! Michel approaches, followed by Tiago and Paul.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t think you have met my son, Paul. Introductions are made, they exchange handshakes.  87.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We were going to go get some coffee and patisserie. Do you want to come with us?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: No, thank you. But I’m planning to meet Frankie later. At the top.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: Peninha.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL
dialogues.text: (to Ilene) Yes, good, then we’ll see you there. They come to a split in the road.

dialogues.speaker: TIAGO
dialogues.text: It’s this way. Tiago and Michel take the turn, but Paul hesitates behind

dialogues.speaker: PAUL PAUL
dialogues.text: Papa, je vous rejoins. Papa, I'll catch up with you.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEL MICHEL
dialogues.text: Oui oui, bien sir. Prends ton Of course, of course. Take temps. your time. They disappear, leaving Ilene and Paul alone. They begin walk together.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I hear you’re moving to New York.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And you live there, is that right?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Twenty three years. Do you know where in the city you’re going to be living?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I thought your mother told me you had a found a place already.  88.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: My mother thinks she knows everything. She has all these plans, you know.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Of course. She’s in a hurry. Paul seems a bit surprised at Ilene’s comment.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: So you know.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m so sorry. If ever you need anything-

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We'll be fine by ourselves, thank you. Ilene is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: You know your mother invited me here.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I know she did. She wanted us to meet. She’s afraid I’m going to end up alone in New York City.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Maybe she just wanted to see me. Frankie and I are good friends, you know.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Can I tell a story, about Frankie?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I want to hear it, Paul. It’s not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: But I want you to hear it. It will help you understand our family a little better. You see, Jimmy's always had a thing for Portugal. We’re all thankful to him for that. It’s a gift he gave us: Portugal. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is probably our fifth or sixth time to come here together. And Sintra particularly, you know they came here on their honeymoon, don’t you? That is their second honeymoon. They had each had others before. But when my mom first started seeing him, he took us on a trip to the Algarve. Have you been?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Praia da Falésia, beautiful beach south of here, and twenty years ago, before the Portugal renaissance, or destruction, depending on who’s talking, it was almost deserted. Really gorgeous. Mom, Jimmy, and Sylvia, his daughter Sylvia. Have you met, Sylvia?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: No, I haven’t.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: She's lovely, a little damaged, but lovely. We all went to the Algarve together. Mom had moved to London, but only for a short time, for a film, but clearly she and Jimmy were also testing the waters, for the new family to be. A family vacation was decided, and off we went. I barely spoke any English at the time. I was just your average French schoolboy, so as you can imagine I was very nervous. Excited, but nervous. Particularly because of Sylvia. I had met her a couple of times, and, really, you might not know it now, but she was the most beautiful girl ever. She was, she is - a few years older than me. I was maybe fifteen, and she was eighteen or nineteen. She had a woman’s body already. A beautiful body. When I saw her in a bikini, oh my God... And I was such a boy! Anyway, it was summer, and hot, and she and I would spend the whole day on the beach together. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe I don’t need to go on. You get the picture, right? Ilene doesn’t answer. Paul continues.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One night, Mom and Jimmy went out to dinner, and we said, Sylvia and I, we were going to stay home, and watch TV. They were showing the movie Grease on TV. You remember. (sings Summer Lovin’) Tell me more, tell me more, did you get very far. Ilene chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know what got into me, because I was actually a very shy boy, pimples, and skinny, and very uncomfortable, but I got up and I started to imitate John Travolta. I grabbed Sylvia so we could dance together, and she screamed! Not because she didn’t want to. No, she was sun burned. And so, naturally, I offered to put some lotion on her shoulders. She took her shirt off. A GIRL trotting on a HORSE comes their way, following a BLONDE TRAINER, who holds the reins of her horse with whi gloves.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When my mom and Jimmy came back, we were having sex on the couch. Me and my soon-to-be step sister. The riders come fast, and Paul and Ilene have to make spa for them to pass by on the road.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As you can imagine, that was the end of this new family idea. I was sent back to live with Michel in Paris. And my mother moved to London. To live with Jimmy and Sylvia. And that was that. Ilene takes it in.  91.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You see, in Portugal, I lost my mother once already. It only seems fitting that I’m here again now. He stops, and looks at Ilene more closely.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's right about one thing: you are very attractive, you know.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Is that a compliment?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Maybe. My mother would like us to get married. Ilene is silent.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think you are the marrying type?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Not to you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I didn’t think so. An uncomfortable moment between them.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: When are you moving?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I don’t know now. Everything is a bit up in the air, as you can imagine, scheduling-wise.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: If it was soon, I would have been happy to introduce you to a few people in New York, but I don’t think I’ll be there all that much longer.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh no. Pity!  40 92.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Yes. I got an offer to work on a series, in London, in fact, for the BBC. I need a break from New York - I’ve been there too long.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I was so looking forward to telling your mother, but now I can’t. I just can’t.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes, I understand. They stand for a moment, together. Nothing more to be sai it seems.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m going to go now, and catch up with my father.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Ok. I’m sure I will see you later.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m sure we will. Paul walks off, back in the direction of Michel and Tiago few feet away, he turns, and calls out to Ilene.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ilene. She turns and stops.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you for listening. She smiles, this time warmly, before they walk their sepa ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s still bright on the beach, but the sunlight is more gentle, casting long shadows as it approaches the horizon Some seagulls fly above the surf, only to dive in head on hunting for fish. On the sand, only a few groups of famil or friends, not as crowded as before.  4l 93. Maya and Pedro come walking along the surf, side by side. They don’t hold hands, but walk very close to each other, silence, watching the waves break. Each is very aware of other’s body next to them; as Maya’s arm swings, it gentl rubs Pedro's, and she prolongs the moment, feeling his sk against hers, extending a finger so it can hold his finge for a brief moment, playfully, romantic. Pedro looks at Maya, as they continue their stroll on the sand, too self conscious to hold hands, but full of desir EXT. PRAIA DAS MACAS/BEACH - DAY 4l A GROUP OF EIGHT BOYS and TWO GIRLS sit in a circle on th sand, with towels, backpacks, beer bottles and cigarettes scattered all around. All attention is on Bento, Pedro’s buddy from the tram, who reads from a notebook.

dialogues.speaker: BENTO
dialogues.text: “What is love if not blazing flames? I asked Grandpa, will he ever get over losing Frankie. Will he ever let go. “You’re asking the wrong question”, he said. “It’s not about getting over, or letting go.” He put his arm around me, and I wondered how this could possibly be about anything else. “It’s about honoring what happened,” he said. “You met a person that awoke something in you. A fire ignited.” There’s laughter all around. Bento continues.

dialogues.speaker: BENTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “The work is to be grateful. Grateful everyday that someone crossed your path and left a mark on you.” When Grandpa left, I looked at my reflection on the water, and wondered; who will be the one to ignite this fire inside of me?” (comments ) Wow!! More laughter, louder. Bento can’t see that, behind him, and Pedro are approaching. He continues to read:  42

dialogues.speaker: BENTO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “And when it happens, I want to hold him and kiss him, our bodies melting into each other, our hearts beating as one.” Maya can still hear the last words. She recognizes her wo and jumps in to grab the diary from Bento’s hands.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?? Caught by surprise, Bento tosses the book to another frie and this friend to another. Maya runs around, trying to grab it from them.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: (in Portuguese) Stop it! Guys! When one of the BOYS plays with Maya, swinging the book around her face like bait, and then tossing it away to another friend, the unexpected happens: Maya pushes the b hard, and he falls to the sand. Maya dives ready to fight some more. It’s a complete surprise, and the boys try to hold her back. Some of them laugh. Pedro gets into the mix, and a fight amongst them ensues. There’s a scream, and laughter, punches and sand throwing around. The book falls on the sand, and Maya immediately grabs it She then grabs her backpack and walks away. Pedro pushes of the boys who continues to laugh, and they fight on the sand. Through an arm lock from the boy, he sees Maya goin away.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maya! INT. QUINTA DE SAO THIAGO/FRANKIE & JIMMY’S SUITE - DAY 4 Jimmy is lying on the bed, his eyes closed. In the distan a piano plays softly. Jimmy opens his eyes, listening to music.  43 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The grand library with an old piano in its center, where Frankie is playing music she knows so well. A CLEANING LADY from the hotel, walks by carrying a bag f of laundry. Frankie smiles, but the lady lowers her head, and discreet. Jimmy enters, and stays by the door frame, admiring the scene, as Frankie continues to play. Her hands glide through the different keys with the ease someone who’s trained, but not a professional. She makes slight mistake, but keeps going, as Jimmy comes to sit ne to her on the stool. She moves a bit to give him space.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Beautiful. Frankie looks into his eyes, as she keeps playing, and se that he’s actually crying, under a forced smile.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Don’t be. It’s sad. It’s very sad, indeed.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yes. The song comes to a natural end, and Frankie reaches to c the piano, but Jimmy stops her.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How about one more.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: No, I’m going to go for a walk, if you don’t mind. I’1l meet you all at Peninha. Frankie gives Jimmy a small kiss on his head, then gets u from the stool and leaves. Jimmy, alone with the piano, the empty room, and the sile Until he strikes a key, any key.  44 45 46 47 48 49 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie comes out of the Quinta, and heads up the long sloping driveway towards the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya runs through the streets of the small beach town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie goes up a path towards Sintra, bordered by an old stone wall, with graffiti etched into the rock. As she goes up the steep incline ahead of her, she pauses a second, catching her breath, but soon starts again, wit determination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting on the tram, Maya is lost in her own thoughts, of beach, and the day, behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving the woods behind, Frankie walks onto the road whe earlier, she had her argument with Paul. After she takes a few steps on the road, she sees somethi that makes her pause. In front of her, the beaten up bouquet of flowers is stil the ground, oblivious to the people and the traffic that by. Frankie picks it up, and smells the flowers. The scen lavender instantly brings memories back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tram makes its way back into the city of Sintra. INSIDE THE TRAM: Maya sits on the aisle, looking at sight MAYA’S POV FROM THE TRAM: The little center of town has b taken over by TOURISTS and BUSES, its cafés and gift shop filled with people from all over the world. Ian is coming around the corner towards the final Tram St  50 97. INSIDE THE TRAM: Some people start to get up and gather t things. Maya recognizes someone on the street, and waves. Ian waves, but notices that Maya is waving at someone els He looks in that direction, and sees Sylvia coming his wa She waves to Maya. Ian and Sylvia, husband and wife, meet, and wait together the tram to come to a stop. Maya steps off, and onto the platform. She embraces her mother so tightly, that Sylvia is a little thrown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ilene walks beside a long wooden rail covered in moss of various tones, going up the hill, creating a dirt path. As she enters the canyon, Ilene runs into Jimmy, surround by magnificent rocks in this mostly desolate area. The wi is constantly blowing, and a mist has started to form.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: How did you find Frankie?

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Beyond recovered.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: She’s a star.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. It’s wonderful... and complicated.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You know, people seldom say “no” to Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I know. She must have been very disappointed with my visit.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: She wasn't expecting you’d show up with a boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Ex-boyfriend.  98. Jimmy looks at Ilene, and raises his eyebrows. Ilene laug

dialogues.speaker: ILENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As soon as we got here, he proposed to me.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: He’s going back to Lisbon, tonight.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Poor Gary.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t know. Don’t get the wrong idea about me, or anything. I’m not some kind of femme fatale.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You must do as you feel.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Did someone famous say that? Jimmy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, just me.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I guess it’s true. I have to be true to myself. But now I admit I regret it a little. It means I'll have to start up again that phase of drinks and meals, and dates with men I hardly know. I’m starting to think maybe I’m too old for it.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Careful there. If you’re old, what am I.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: It’s completely different for you, men. The older you are, the more attractive you get.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Is that right?  99.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Oh, you must know. I’m not going to name names, but you had a good fan base in New York. Ilene smiles. Now Jimmy

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: You know, maybe you need a change. Take some time off. Travel.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Maybe. I’ve always loved New York. Really had a love affair with it for the longest time. But lately I find every little thing about it irritating. The amount of people, the constant development, the noise, the terrible subways. laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s true! All my favorite restaurants are gone, or going soon.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Not Keen’s!

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: But you can’t eat at Keen’s every night.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Why not? Ilene laughs again. It feels good to talk honestly.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: You know, it’s funny. If Gary had proposed to me in New York, maybe I would've answered differently. But here, I don’t know. There’s something about this place. I actually felt strong. (pause) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ILENE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know Jimmy, I hope to be in London before the end of the year. There’s a job, and it’s for several months. I hope I can be a support for Frankie. And for you.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: When will you be there?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Soon. I’m waiting to hear confirmation from the production.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Please, let me know. I’d love to show you around. Ilene stands still, and hugs herself, tightening her sweatshirt around her shoulders, protecting against the w She turns to Jimmy, who is now face to face with her.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: It’s gotten chilly all of a sudden.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: I know. I get it now why people say that Sintra is the place where winter goes to spend the summer. Ilene laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I understand that completely, but it sounds true. Jimmy takes off his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: Here take this...

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: No, please. I'll be fine....

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: wees I can’t watch you shaking like that....

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: ...It was just silly not to bring something with me.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY
dialogues.text: wees I could be held responsible if something happens to you. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even if this will be a touch big for you, it will at least keep you warm. He puts the jacket over her shoulders, and she wraps it around herself. They stand silently for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shall we continue up, and see if the others have arrived?

dialogues.speaker: ILENE
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course. They start walking together, higher up the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On top of the hill, Frankie moves slowly along a terrace outside the abandoned sanctuary, a yellow building with crumbling walls. The wind blows and a mist surrounds her, she walks along. But Frankie is paying no attention to nature. Instead, she is observing the scene taking place below. FRANKIE’S POV: Frankie sees Jimmy and Ilene. They look go together, and there’s a lightness in Jimmy we haven’t see before. The wind blows a strong gust, and Frankie has to hold the fragile wooden rail hard. FRANKIE’S POV: Jimmy takes his jacket off, and puts it ov Ilene’s shoulders. She is an unexpected witness to this gentle action, and t future that it might herald.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At another spot on the hill, Michel stands with his binoculars to his eyes. He drops them, and we can see in face that he has seen everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul is walking up the road, when he passes by the ruins an old house. He slows down when he sees a COUPLE making against the walls.  54 55 102. The hands of the WOMAN caress the back of the MAN’s head. is wearing a shiny bracelet. Paul comes closer. He can’t believe his eyes, but there’s mistake: this is Frankie’s bracelet, on this woman’s wris as she strokes her man’s head. The couple is suddenly aware of Paul’s presence, and they pull apart. They are the flower sellers, Bianca and her boyfriend Joao Miguel, who were last seen fighting earlie on. They see Paul, and decide to leave. Paul keeps on his way, but turns around to catch a glimps the couple walking hand in hand, going down the road. The Vendor steals a kiss on the Bianca’s neck, while she laug very much in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a small chapel perched on top of the hillside. Frankie is inside, an abandoned ruin made of stone walls wooden floors. Instead of doors and windows, just their g between walls. It’s dark, quiet and there’s nothing to see, like a death chamber. Frankie touches the walls, feeling the rock, and listening to her own footsteps. She sees a stream of wate running down the old wall. She extends her hand, and feel the water on her skin. Outside, a few clouds fly by against the still blue sky, taken by strong winds. Frankie hears a sound, and in the rear of the chapel, alm in darkness, she sees Tiago, with his cell phone and a li cigarette. He and Frankie look at each other for a moment, warily, a then Frankie starts moving slowly, leaving the Sanctuary, heading towards the light outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie walks outside the chapel, and onto a rocky pastur The wind blasts and a cloud blows intermittently against sky. She tightens up her jacket, protecting herself again sudden chill. She walks ahead, to the edge of the cliff in front of her and the long drop below.  103. Frankie looks out to the sea. Time stops for long moment. And then she turns to see what’s behind her. Coming to meet her from different directions are Jimmy an Ilene, and Paul. Not far are Ian and Sylvia, with Maya be them. In the rear is Michel, with Tiago helping him navig the rocks and the climb. And then, as if always, Jimmy is beside Frankie. He puts arm around her. She feels his presence, his body, his wei and then -- before the others have even fully arrived to the view -- Frankie is ready to go, ready to continue.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: On y va? And without pause or hesitation, she leads Jimmy and the back towards the town, back towards what’s ahead for her, all of them. As she arrives at Michel, he puts up a fuss for a moment to missing the view. But Frankie insists, and he and Tiag turn around and follow the rest, as the head down and awa Clouds come and go. And then, the sky clears up momentarily, and we marvel at spectacular view of the sun setting on the entire Sintra coastline down below - the mountains, the towns, the tree tops, the white beach, and the infinite ocean.
